questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the emergency room with a generalised seizure following a high-grade fever. What is the first-line drug of choice for seizure control in this setting?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The child is suffering from febrile seizures, and among the given options, diazepam is the first-line drug of choice for seizure control for this condition.

  • Febrile seizures are convulsions seen in children between 6 and 60 months, most often at 12-18 months, occurring with fever ≥38°C but without CNS infection or metabolic disturbance.
  • Simple febrile seizures are brief, generalised tonic-clonic episodes lasting under 15 minutes and not recurring within 24 hours, while complex febrile seizures are longer than 15 minutes, focal, or recurrent.
  • Febrile status epilepticus lasts over 30 minutes.
  • Treatment does not involve routine, continuous antiepileptic therapy for simple febrile seizures.
  • Acute seizures lasting beyond 5 minutes may be treated with lorazepam, midazolam, or diazepam, and intermittent therapy with oral or rectal benzodiazepines may be used in recurrent cases.
  • Long-term continuous antiepileptic drug use is discouraged due to risks outweighing benefits.
  • Antipyretics reduce discomfort but do not prevent recurrence, while iron deficiency increases risk.

Explanation of other options:

Ethosuximide (Option B): Ethosuximide is a calcium channel blocker used in absence seizures.

Valproate (Option C): Valproate is a broad-spectrum antiseizure drug used to manage absence, myoclonic, focal, and tonic-clonic seizures.

Phenytoin (Option D): Phenytoin is a widely used antiseizure drug effective for focal and generalised tonic-clonic seizures, including focal to bilateral tonic-clonic and tonic-clonic of unknown onset, but it is not useful for absence seizures. Beyond epilepsy, phenytoin may help in trigeminal and related neuralgias, though carbamazepine is often preferred, and it is also used in managing certain cardiac arrhythmias.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with fever and cough. A chest x-ray was done, which showed the following findings. Which of the following is the most likely underlying pathology?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given x-ray image shows right upper lobe consolidation and is consistent with a diagnosis of pneumonia, as suggested by the clinical features of fever and cough.

  • Consolidation is defined as the replacement of air in the pulmonary airspaces with fluid, protein, cells, or other materials.
  • On radiographs or CT scans, it presents as one or more relatively uniform opacities that obscure pulmonary vessels but cause little or no volume loss.
  • Unlike ground-glass opacities, which may only partially fill the airspaces, consolidation reflects more complete filling, usually indicating airspace disease.
  • The differential diagnosis takes into account the pattern, distribution, associated findings such as lymph node enlargement, hemoptysis, or fever, and patient history.
  • Substances that may cause consolidation include water (oedema), blood (haemorrhage), pus (pneumonia), cells (neoplasm), fat (lipoid pneumonia), or protein (alveolar proteinosis).
  • While most cases are due to airspace filling, it may also occur from interstitial disease encroaching into alveoli.
  • Air bronchograms are frequently seen, representing air-filled bronchi within consolidated lung, although they may be absent if bronchi are obstructed or filled with blood, pus, or tumour tissue.
  • Diagnosis typically combines clinical, laboratory, and radiographic findings.

Explanation of other options:

Right upper lobe collapse (Option A): Atelectasis refers to incomplete inflation of part or all of the lung, leading to reduced lung volume. The term 'collapse' is often used interchangeably, but should be reserved for cases of complete atelectasis. In right upper lobe atelectasis, the minor and major fissures shift, and the lobe flattens against the mediastinum, creating a triangular shadow on imaging. A juxtaphrenic peak, a sharply defined triangular opacity, may also be seen, often due to upward retraction of the pleura. Additionally, large hilar tumours can produce the 'S sign of Golden,' a reverse S-shaped configuration of the minor fissure, which is highly indicative of pulmonary carcinoma and, though initially described for the right upper lobe, may be found in atelectasis of any lobe. It is shown below.

Right upper lobe abscess (Option B): Lung abscesses typically present as fluid-filled cavities with thick walls and peripheral enhancement, often showing an air-fluid level as shown below. Because of their rounded shape, this air-fluid level appears equal in length on both posteroanterior and lateral views.

Bronchogenic carcinoma (Option D): An acquired cause of unilateral pulmonary artery obstruction, marked by the presence of a hilar mass as shown below. It is also an unlikely condition in a 3-year-old child.

choices.text: Both nevirapine and zidovudine for 12 weeks, along with exclusive breast milk feeding
Nevirapine for 6 weeks with exclusive breastfeeding
No breastfeeding and initiate exclusive formula feeding

questions.text: A pregnant woman is diagnosed with HIV infection at 34 weeks of gestation. Her viral load was 1200 copies/mL, and she was then started on ART. She delivers a 2.5 kg term baby at 38 weeks. What is the most appropriate postnatal prophylaxis for the newborn?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most appropriate postnatal prophylaxis for a newborn born to a retropositive mother with a viral load of 1200 copies/mL is administration of both nevirapine and zidovudine for 12 weeks, along with exclusive breastmilk feeding.

  • Despite advances in HIV treatment, infants remain at risk of infection during pregnancy, delivery, or breastfeeding, with nearly half of new child infections linked to breastfeeding.
  • To address this, the WHO emphasises universal testing and treatment for pregnant women, retesting HIV-negative women during pregnancy and breastfeeding, and enhanced prophylaxis for infants whose mothers did not receive effective ART early.
  • Infants considered high risk include:
    • Those born to mothers diagnosed at delivery or postpartum
    • Infected during pregnancy or breastfeeding
    • Starting ART late or on ART for less than 4 weeks
    • Failing to achieve viral suppression (viral load copies > 1000/ ml)
  • These infants should receive dual prophylaxis with zidovudine and nevirapine for six weeks, which can be extended to 12 weeks in breastfeeding cases. (Options B, C, and D ruled out)
  • WHO infant feeding guidelines stress continued breastfeeding with ART, as the benefits outweigh risks, with prophylaxis beyond 4-6 weeks adding little benefit if the mother's viral load is suppressed.
  • The 2021 guidelines recommend viral load testing for all pregnant women with HIV at 34-36 weeks or at delivery at the latest, if not already done.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely in a neonate presenting with congenital hypothyroidism, decreased T3 and T4 levels, decreased radioactive iodine uptake, but a normal thyroid on ultrasound?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely condition in a neonate presenting with congenital hypothyroidism, decreased T3 and T4 levels, along with decreased radioactive iodine uptake, is a defect in the iodine transporter.


The following image shows a baby with jaundice due to congenital hypothyroidism.

Explanation of other options:

Thyroid dyshormonogenesis (Option A): Defects in thyroid hormone production, known as dyshormonogenesis, can be identified through newborn screening.. Due to the trophic influence of elevated TSH on thyroid follicular cells, affected infants frequently develop a goitre. It is associated with increased uptake of radioactive iodine.

Thyroid agenesis (Option B): Thyroid agenesis is characterised by reduced uptake of radioactive iodine, but this option can be ruled out since the thyroid gland is visualised on ultrasound.

Iodine deficiency (Option C): It is the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism and is characterised by increased uptake on scintigraphy.

questions.text: During examination of a neonate, an index finger was found missing along with multiple deformities of all four limbs, as shown in the image given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features of a missing index finger, along with deformities of all four limbs, is suggestive of amniotic band syndrome.

  • Amniotic band disruption presents with a wide spectrum of deformities caused by fibrous tissue bands encircling and constricting fetal parts.
  • The extremities are frequently involved, where the bands can cause amputations of fingers and toes, fixed deformities of the hands, or pseudodactyly.
  • Bands may also encircle larger regions, leading to thoracoabdominal wall defects with herniation of abdominal and thoracic contents.
  • Craniofacial abnormalities can occur, including absent calvarium, facial clefts, and large encephaloceles.
  • Additionally, bands may constrict areas such as the ankle, producing deformational defects and amputations.
  • Overall, the disruption sequence is marked by variable combinations of limb reductions, craniofacial malformations, and body wall defects, all directly related to the location and severity of the constricting amniotic bands.

Explanation of other options:

Arthrogryposis multiplex congenita (Option A): Arthrogryposis multiplex congenita is a descriptive condition characterised by the presence of two or more nonprogressive congenital joint contractures at birth, often linked with muscle weakness and reduced mobility due to abnormal muscle fibre contraction. The primary cause is fetal akinesia, leading to a sequence of abnormalities such as multiple joint contractures, craniofacial anomalies, and pulmonary hypoplasia. The following image shows an infant with amyoplasia or classic arthrogryposis.

CTEV (Option B): Congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV), or clubfoot, is a deformity caused by malalignment of the calcaneo-talar-navicular complex, characterised by cavus, adductus, varus, and equinus (CAVE). Clinically, affected feet show cavus, adductus, varus, equinus, calf atrophy, and may also present with foot shortening, internal tibial torsion, leg-length discrepancy, and occasionally coexist with developmental dysplasia of the hip.

Syndactyly (Option D): Syndactyly occurs when the digits fail to separate during development, resulting in fused fingers or toes. It is among the more common anomalies of the upper limb. The condition can be classified as simple (skin attachments only), complicated (involving bone and tendon), complete (fusion to the tips, including the nail), or incomplete (partial webbing).
